etymologies: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wind and German Wind, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin ventus

definitions: the perceptible natural movement of the air, especially in the form of a current of air blowing from a particular direction

examples.text: the wind howled about the building
an easterly wind
gusts of wind

shortDefinitions: perceptible natural movement of air

definitions: relating to or denoting energy obtained from harnessing the wind with windmills or wind turbines.
shortDefinitions: of energy obtained from harnessing wind with windmills or wind turbines

definitions: used to suggest something very fast, unrestrained, or changeable

examples.text: run like the wind
she could be as free and easy as the wind

shortDefinitions: used to suggest something very fast or changeable

definitions: used in reference to an influence or tendency that cannot be resisted

examples.text: a wind of change

shortDefinitions: used in reference to influence or tendency that cannot be resisted

definitions: used in reference to an impending situation

examples.text: he had seen which way the wind was blowing

shortDefinitions: used of impending situation

definitions: the rush of air caused by a fast-moving body.
shortDefinitions: rush of air caused by fast-moving body

definitions: a scent carried by the wind, indicating the presence or proximity of an animal or person.
shortDefinitions: scent carried by wind, indicating presence or proximity of animal or person

definitions: breath as needed in physical exertion or in speech

examples.text: he waited while Jez got his wind back
she hit the floor with a thud that knocked the wind out of her

shortDefinitions: breath as needed in physical exertion, speech, etc.

definitions: the power of breathing without difficulty while running or making a similar continuous effort

examples.text: he waited while Jerry got his wind back

shortDefinitions: power of breathing without difficulty while running or making similar continuous effort

definitions: air swallowed while eating or gas generated in the stomach and intestines by digestion.
shortDefinitions: air swallowed while eating or gas generated in stomach and intestines by digestion

definitions: empty, pompous, or boastful talk; meaningless rhetoric.
shortDefinitions: empty, pompous, or boastful talk

definitions: wind instruments, or specifically woodwind instruments, forming a band or a section of an orchestra

examples.text: these passages are most suitable for wind alone
wind players

shortDefinitions: wind instruments

phrases.text: it's an ill wind that blows no good
take the wind out of someone's sails

definitions: cause (someone) to have difficulty breathing because of exertion or a blow to the stomach

examples.text: the fall nearly winded him

shortDefinitions: cause someone to have difficulty breathing

definitions: detect the presence of (a person or animal) by scent

examples.text: the birds could not have seen us or winded us

shortDefinitions: detect presence of person or animal by scent

definitions: sound (a bugle or call) by blowing

examples.text: but scarce again his horn he wound

shortDefinitions: sound bugle or call by blowing

phrases.text: it's an ill wind that blows no good
take the wind out of someone's sails

etymologies: Old English windan ‘go rapidly’, ‘twine’, of Germanic origin; related to wander and wend

definitions: move in or take a twisting or spiral course

examples.text: the path wound among olive trees

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move in or take twisting or spiral course

definitions: pass (something) around a thing or person so as to encircle or enfold

examples.text: he wound a towel around his midriff

shortDefinitions: pass something round thing or person so as

definitions: repeatedly twist or coil (a length of something) around itself or a core

examples.text: Anne wound the wool into a ball

shortDefinitions: repeatedly twist or coil length of something round itself or core

definitions: be repeatedly twisted or coiled

examples.text: large vines wound around every tree

shortDefinitions: be twisted or coiled

definitions: wrap or surround (a core) with a coiled length of something

examples.text: devices wound with copper wire

shortDefinitions: wrap or surround core with coiled length of something

definitions: make (a clock or other device, typically one operated by clockwork) operate by turning a key or handle

examples.text: he wound City Hall's clock every day until he retired at the age of 92
she was winding the gramophone

shortDefinitions: make operate by turning key or handle

definitions: turn (a key or handle) repeatedly around and around

examples.text: I wound the handle as fast as I could

shortDefinitions: turn key or handle repeatedly round and round

definitions: cause (an audio or video tape or a film) to move back or forward to a desired point

examples.text: wind your tape back and listen to make sure everything is okay

shortDefinitions: cause to move back or forwards to desired point

definitions: hoist or draw (something) with a windlass, winch, or similar device.
shortDefinitions: hoist or draw something with windlass, winch, or similar device

definitions: a twist or turn in a course.
shortDefinitions: twist or turn in course

definitions: a single turn made when winding.
shortDefinitions: single turn made when winding
